Also, of note, they serve the most delicious coconut ice cream in a coconut shell. with strawberries.

So glad I got to try their food during the Baltimore dollar stroll! I got their tofu summer roll and the nam salad - both were really yummy! The only thing was I got the salad thinking I needed to get my daily need of veggies, but the summer roll ended up being more veggie heavy..the salad was still good! Just lots of fried things so it didn't feel as healthy as expected

I must have ordered the wrong dish (and my sis in law must have, too) because I did not enjoy my meal at all. 

I ordered beef thai basil. My experience with thai basil dishes is that they, at the very least, have some miggyfiggy thai basil in them. This bowl of soupy veggies did not have a hint or trace of anything resembling thai basil. Literally. None. Not like, "oh man, i love thai basil i sure wish they put more of it in here!" It was just completely absent from the dish.

This place also doesn't take cards. I totally get that lots of little cafes in West Philly don't take cards. It's inconvenient and I hate it but I get that when most of your transactions are $1.75 cups of coffee, accepting debit and credit is not a necessity. But when the average dish on your menu is $10+ being cash only is ridiculous to me. 

I just don't see why I'd ever return. meh
BYOB and so so good, I so enjoy going to this place, the people are friendly the people that eat here are friendly, and the food is good and the spices are hot hot hot. Come and enjoy

charming locale, badass food!

Appetizers:
*Sticky Tamarind - strips of fried tofu, plated on a bed of mixed greens with a tamarind dipping sauce - fabulous!
*Shredded Green Papaya salad - crisp, fresh - delicious.
Entrees:
* Panaeng Curry with shrimp, 4 star heat -  a spiciness that blended perfectly with the sweetness of the peanut sauce - declared the biggest winner by all present,
*Green Curry with tofu, 3 star heat -  slightly sweet with basil & perhaps annise - fantastic flavor!
*Yellow Curry with tofu, 4 star heat - this is my friend's go-to dish, he orders it on nearly every visit!

thoroughly enjoyable!

I recently moved to the neighborhood and always wanted to try this restaurant since I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE Thai food. 

it was last Friday, I was soooooooooo tired and drained from my hectic-crazy work week. Glad I went early,so, i could soak up the intimate atmosphere, sipping Jasmine tea while listening to the traditional Laotian-Thai music. first, I ordered an appetizer: I was channeling my favorite Thai restaurant in Chicago (Joys) and thought I should try the fresh, vegetarian spring rolls. I had one before from Vientiane, as I did the Baltimore Ave stroll in August. Yum! It was light and tasted nice with the sauces it comes with. Then, my entree: I have always LOVED Thai noodle dishes. Nice fragrance and spices. Yum! The  Vegetarian Pad See Eiu  is chocked with veggies and Tofu. It has a nice flavor too.

I am glad the restaurant is a mere couple of blocks from my apartment. 
It was very good. PS when I walked by after my coffeehouse visit to Satellite Cafe, I saw the cafe was filled to capacity later that evening. Awwwww, come early, come often!

Reading the other reviews, there must have been something wrong tonight.

It took 1 hour to get our food and the restaurant was not even very busy.
You would think that waiting for an hour would make everything taste better on account of us being hungry, but it did not.  The food was serviceable, but it was not worth waiting for an hour and definitely not worth going back for.  I will definitely look for a different place next time I am in the mood for southeast asian food.

Absolutely delicious and cheap food. 
I came here for a birthday with a party of about 14 people. Service was noted to be excellent. 

There was so many known Thai places in the city, and I never heard about Vientiane Cafe so I was a bit skeptical to think that it would be any good. But I was proven wrong. 

Thai tea was delicious and on point, although I have never tried bad Thai tea at any restaurants yet. 
I was debating over coconut or tom yum soup and I gave their coconut soup a go, and it was delicious. Chicken was perfectly cooked and the flavor of the broth was full of flavor.

P.S: DON'T MISS OUT ON THE NAAM SALAD FOR APPETIZER. It's like Thai version of lettuce wrap but the stuffing is so crunchy and flavorful with a bit tangy and spicy kick. I'm obsessed! 

For dinner, I got the green curry with chicken and it was divine. Texture of the chicken was prefect and the flavor was just amazing. I just wish that their sauce was a little creamier than watery, that's all. 
I'm already craving to come back here again, and I'll be sure to try their drunken noodles next time.

Update after few more visit: I returned back and tried their drunken noodles and they're literally the best drunken noddles I ever had. It's called pad kee mao.
Best Thai food I've EVER had including in Thailand!!! Unbelievable. Everything is amazing!!!

Love this place. BYOB. Lao and Thai food. You can get things spicy 1-5 stars. Fair warning, five stars will make you cry. Lots of vegan, vegetarian and gluten free options. This place is great for adventurous eaters. Vietiene has several authentic options that some americans might cringe at; like papaya salad with soft shell crab. That being said they also serve the typical food you would expect to see on a thai menu like green curry or Tom yum soup. I've been going here for years and it's consistently yummy food that anyone could love. Never had a complaint about the service.
Fantastic, quaint, and welcoming!  Most things can be made vegetarian, which means many options to choose from.  I especially enjoyed the banana chocolate spring rolls.

One of my favorite places to eat.  Great place to take a vegetarian friend too, because any of their dishes can be made without meat.  Don't forget, they are cash only, and BYO.  Not open on Sundays.  Everything on the menu is amazing.  My favorite is the Panang Curry dish. With shrimp or chicken.  

When I was looking for a new apartment, this restaurant was one of my top reasons not to leave West Philly.  I left anyways, but there is a great sadness in my heart when I remember that Vientiane is no longer the closest restaurant to my house.

They do take out orders too.

I went here with a friend for University City Dining Days recently and got the naam salad, panang curry, and mango sticky rice. I was really excited because of the average rating of 4 stars on yelp, but I wasn't really a fan of Vientiane by the end. 

Food: 
The naam salad was delicious, and the panang curry was pretty good, but they used a little too much oil -- I could see the oil separating from the curry on my plate. As for the mango sticky rice, they used a little too much coconut milk. The small mound of sticky rice was completely covered in the milk, rather than being well-balanced. Overall, I would give the food 3.5 stars.

Service:
This was where I detracted 1 star because I was pretty ok with the food at all, but the service was extremely slow. In addition, they messed up the dessert orders for both my friend and me, so I had to go to the front desk and wait for a waiter to come out to tell him of the mistake. In addition, the service didn't seem well-organized, as there were long periods of time in the back of the restaurant where a waiter did not even check in on the tables. I would be ok with this, except that the waiting time was inordinately long and that this was during Dining Days, where the restaurant should at least try to be at their best.

Overall, go for a nice long (like 1.5 hour long or more) dinner, but if you're in a rush, skip.

Vientiane Cafe is a terrific neighborhood gem gently nestled along a string of dive bars and fellow ethnic joints on Baltimore Ave.  We came here on the recommendation of a friend of mine while entertaining out of town guests in search of the classic Philadelphia BYO experience.  Armed with two bottles of wine, the six of us enjoyed a filling dinner of delicious and cheap Thai and Laotian food that satisfied our hunger and kept our wallet light.

I enjoyed the Lad Na with Beef, which is sort of like a Pad See Ew except with a slightly thinner sauce and more vegetables.  The broccoli was crisp, the beef was flavorful and juicy, and the noodles were done just right.  Everything in the dish worked perfectly together.  The BF and I also split a Nam Salad; some sort of lettuce wrap thing that tasted pretty good although I have no idea what the filling was (kind of reminded me of Bac-os?).  Not as good as the noodles in my opinion.

The service could have been slightly better (it took them forever to get us the wine glasses, although to their credit we were a large party and it was very crowded for the later side of a Friday night), but I was still very pleased with the food, ambiance, and overall value.  Definitely a place I would be happy to return to for a low-key dinner or even take out.  Also, at just under $20 per person with tax and tip included, it's extremely reasonable.  Do make sure you bring cash though.

One my favorite restaurants in all of Philadelphia. They always have plenty of customers and for good reason. Their food is authentic and addictive. The vegetarian papaya salad is just perfection(warning can get extremely spicy so tell them to keep it at 2 out of 5 spice level). Their curries, from red to panang, are all excellent. The flavors are not to be beaten. I also love their homemade stuffed Lao sausages. I dont even live in Philadelphia and have eaten here about 4 times in the past two months. Go here.

Cozy little BYOB with limited seating, so get there early.  The food was great, I had the penang(sp?) curry and everyone else got the pad thai.  The curry was the best I've ever had, the pad thai was excellent, but I've had better.  We visited for dining days so we all got a desert too, all of them were excellent, especially the banana and chocolate spring roll.  The prices on the menu were very cheap considering the portion size and quality.  Would definitely recommend if you're in the area and you can go to dock street first and grab some beer for your meal.

All my friends love Vientiane but I just can't bring myself to like it very much. All the food I've had from here has been mediocre and the layout of the restaurant is a little weird so when you are stuck on the narrow side they sometimes forget about you and the service gets slowed down a lot. It is a BYO which is nice and my friends always like their dishes but I am just never overly impressed. I had the cornish hen this time and the meat was very dry and the vegetables weren't cooked much at all. The one detail I do like is that they put their rice in little baskets that make me happy to look at.

being new to the area, i checked my yelp android phone app to see "what's hot" near me, and i found this restaurant close to where i was staying.  i loove thai food, and they had a killer lunch special, so i dropped in one day for lunch.  i ordered the coconut soup, dumplings (i know, not very thai, but i can never resist dumplings), and pad thai (my usual go-to when trying out a new thai place).

- coconut soup: yum. normal. as expected. downed the broth, left the veggies.
- dumplings: soggy, mushy, fell apart.  disappointed.  my bad for ordering chinese at a thai place.
- pad thai: from the first bite it just tasted too soy saucy.  it didn't taste like pad thai to me.  very, very disappointing.  

i might try this place out again to give it another shot, but if a thai restaurant can't get pad thai right each time they make it (in my opinion), then i'm not sure it's worth trying out a second time :T

I came here with a friend for the University City Dining Days thing ($15 for 3-course meal). Do know this is cash only, BYOB. When I first arrived, the staff seemed to make a big deal that they couldn't find our reservation (though my friend said she had made one), despite the number of empty tables. She finally seated us at a table near the door. At no point was there a line of awaiting diners so it seemed like they made a big deal out of it for no reason.

The food wasn't bad but the portions were a bit on the small side. Maybe this was due to the Dining Days deal.  The curry entree I got was an OK size but the appetizer and dessert were tiny.  The banana-chocolate spring roll was almost dwarf-sized and definitely small enough to rule out any sort of sharing.  

Maybe I'll come back here and try the non-Dining Days dishes to see if the portion size will impress but my experience here was just OK.

We went here on a weeknight and had the curry shrimp with sticky rice and chicken pho. The food was excellent, everything arrived in a timely manner and the portions were generous. If you're wondering the food keeps well for leftovers. I highly recommend the restaurant if you've got a hankering for Asian food and are in the area.

This is a good neighborhood BYOB. Seating is limited for large groups so I would recommend a reservation and still possibly expect a wait, it is a great fit for two people though (they have a lot of two person tables). 
Food is decent but I still haven't found my "go-to" dish.

$$$ Cash Only

Came here for lunch on a weekend, they have a lunch special that cost just under $10 with your choice of soup, appetizer, and main course. 

I had their Tom Yum Soup - it was spicy with a lot of veges which I liked. My friend had their coconut soup which I felt was a little on the sweet side. I had steamed vegetable dumplings - nothing special there. My friend had chicken skewers and we both really enjoyed their peanut sauce. Our main lunch meal was pad thai. I had leftovers after, it has a lot more vegetables than most chicken pad thai places I've had before.

Small, quiet and cute. A little pricey but portions were definitely worth the price.

Take your girlfriend here. She will love you forever. Try the stuffed talapia. Or the Panang. Or the pineapple fried rice. Great menu, plenty of vegetarian options, and plenty of spice! Good prices too. Take your date here. She'll be impressed and you wont break the bank.
Excellent food. Friendly staff.  Good to eat in or take out. Lots of veggie options. Great small plates and entrees. I have never been disappointed.

I have been coming to this restaurant for a few years now and I've never been disappointed. The food is fantastic and the customer service is superb! I enjoyed all the dishes here but I especially like the papaya salad extra spicy and Laos sausage (it comes with this authentic sauce that you dip in). It goes great with sticky rice. Most authentic thai/laos spot in Philadelphia!

This place can be a bit snug on the on hours, but the wait and packed-ness is well worth it. The food is excellent, and it's not just excellent for being cheap; it's excellent, period. Though I might be mangling spellings here, the Bahn-Xeo appetizer is amazing, with or without accompanying sauces, while all the noodle dished -- particularly the Pad See-Ew and Lad Na -- are sizable and scrumptious. Plus, in my opinion, they taste even better cold the next day. On to the desserts, all of which are near incomparable. The mango sticky rice is faboo, though you can definitely get that same goods elsewhere. Try the spring rolls and/or rice pudding for something new and different.

i love the renovations!  the restaurant is now more spacious and seats more people.  lots of hits and misses here.  

love:  homemade sausage (well seasoned and great to share with a group); duck curry (this is the largest portion of duck that i have ever been served for a duck curry.  the meat is meaty and not overcooked), deep fried catfish (hit or miss, when done right it is crispy but not dried, when done wrong, it just tastes bad); the sticky rice that comes with your entree (served in a small bamboo container that keeps your rice warm and fresh).

meh:  paneang curry (i love peanut butter, but not peanut butter curry); cornish hen (looked and tasted like chicken than cornish hen).

the service is always spot on.  i love the family business feel and they are always accomodating to large parties.

overall, a good place to go with the family.

Came here with a group of 3 friends and was seated right away due to us making a reservation beforehand. We ordered our drinks first, one friend and I ordered the Thai Iced Tea and another friend got the red sello drink. The Thai iced tea was great, it had the perfect amount of sweetness and was very much enjoyable. But on the other hand, the sello drink looked cool with the pink color but tasted very watery. Which was very disappointing. Moving onto food, we ordered appetizers, which were the homemade beef jerky and sticky tamarind chicken wings. Both were good and flavorful. As for our entrees, we decided to do a "family style" meal and ordered more than 1 entree and share. We got the duck Penang curry and chicken laab. The curry soup was extremely thick and did not have enough flavor and the chicken laab was good but lacked some flavor. 

Overall, I feel that this place would be great to get a little taste of authentic lao/thai food. But personally, I have had authentic, homemade lao/thai food and I feel like this place lacks some flavor in their dishes. Would recommend if you want to try some lao/thai food but personally will not be going back.
Great for taking out or dining in.  Very friendly, quick service, and super food.  Reasonable prices, too.  I have tried several dishes here and have yet to be disappointed.

I don't like to give reviews, but my dining partner and I ordered an entree that tasted like cat food. very terrible. 

it's byob though.

I had a perfect meal at Vientiane cafe tonight!!! I got the king thai soup which was spicy and delightful, nice lemongrass and lime flavors, and my boo for excellent pad thai. We started off with an amazing Laotian crepe with two different sauces - it was crispy and full of nice veggies and tofu. Also, great dumplings. My favorite restaurant for an easy and fun West Philly night!

Fantastic food, excellent service, and romantic ambience. Everyone in my party really enjoyed their food and the prices were very reasonable. A wonderful find! Also accessible for persons with mobility impairment.  Highly recommend.

This place has always been good for a quality lunch or dinner on the cheap, and now we finally review it.

We ordered a special egg and fish-chili sauce appetizer, the bbq cornish hen, and the red curry. 

The egg and chili appetizer was a thinly fried spiced egg served with a dish of chili sauce and rice, but the taste was really lovely. It was definitely an appetizing start to the evening. The bbq hen was a dry barbecue that came with a sweet and sour dipping sauce. The hen itself was cooked very well. Finally, the curry was superb.

The service is always reasonably good here, and even though they are popular for dinner, our table had enough room around it so we could relax.

I have been following these people throughout the city for the last 10yrs.  They first operated out of their backyard under a blue tarp, served beer for 2 bucks, then was re-located to a wing shop by Drexel, and then was kicked out and moved back to their house but only secretly offering takeout from their house.  So I was quite happy to see that in the last few years they've been able to relocate to their own, cute BYO on Baltimore.

Although the food doesn't seem quite as good as the days it was operating out of their backyard, it's still pretty solid.  The green papaya salad is delicious (but has a lot of fish sauce if you are okay with that), the pad thai has thinner, less traditional pad thai noodles which I actually like better,  isn't greasy and very flavorful.

Over the past few years, Vientiane has remained one of my go-to BYO choices in Philadelphia. 

The food here is so flavorful and always well-prepared. Some of my favorite dishes are: Vegetarian Naam Salad, Red Curry, Pad See Ew, and Pad Kee Mow. I don't know what they put in that salad but it's good. Really good. I first had it at the Baltimore Avenue Stroll for like $3 and now I have to order it every time I go to Vientiane. I've introduced it to a bunch of my friends too and they can't get enough. Definitely one of the underrated items on the menu. I'm all about the flavors and trust me, it doesn't get better than Vientiane. 

The only downsides are that it's cash only and usually pretty busy. Service can get slow when they are packed (which they usually are). However, these minor issues are signficantly outweighed by the benefits of the BYO, price, and food quality. I'll miss Vientiane for sure when I move out of Philly!

I'm a huge thai food fan, but normally I stick to pad thai, two nights ago we went to Vientiane and while enjoying the weather outside I decide to try the crazy pineapple fried rice with chicken... and well, i think i have a new favorite

I love Vientiane!  The prices are fair, the staff is excellent, and the food is delicious.  In addition, they really understand vegan food, including the fact that it doesn't contain fish.  I especially recommend the ginger tofu and the aw lao, but there are many other good dishes, as well.  This is the best restaurant in West Philly, and you can BYOB.

Where do I begin?! 

I absolutely love Vientiane Cafe (even though I may not be pronouncing it correctly, haha)! Do not let the poorly lit entrance fool you, the food here is amazing. 

First visit: I came here with a sister and friend for their dinner special. This comprised of a soup/salad, followed by an appetizer and ended with an entree. I remember getting their seaweed salad, spring rolls and shrimp drunken noodles. OMG! Amazingggg.. It was so good that I took some to-go. 

Location/ Service/ Decor: The restaurant is located on Baltimore Ave. There is nothing fancy to this establishment, I actually wish they put a little more effort into the entrance and decor because I can see how it may turn people away. Service was fine. 

Restaurant is BYOB. 

Craving Thai fried rice, I decided to order take-out from Vientiane. I got their Basil fried rice and opted the protein for more vegetables. The rice was amazzzzzingggg. The aroma of the food took up my entire car.. it was sooo hard not to eat it before getting home.

Overall, great food and reasonably priced. Would recommend!!

Vientiane is cute and casual little neighborhood BYOB self-described as Laotian. I'm a big fan of the pad thai, which is rich in flavor and served with still-crunchy broccoli and carrots, and you can't really go wrong with an appetizer of fresh spring rolls or edamame. Most of the food is just OK, but there are a handful of really excellent dishes.

If you're planning to go, make sure to bring cash, because they don't take credit cards and have no ATM inside. They also do take reservations, so keep that in mind, as they do fill up on Friday and Saturday nights.

This place has great Thai food, but it recently raised its prices!! A beef pad thai is now $15 and a chicken pad thai is now $14 - we ordered these for takeout and it was seriously not worth it for the size you get. They also didn't tell us the total cost over the phone when we made the order, nor give us a receipt when we paid. Seems like a crappy way to treat local customers. Really disappointed! :(

This place is yummy. Great Pad Thai which is the standard, and definitely my fav. dish.
I went with my boyfriend who is Indian and he appreciated all the spice they had, which even made him sweat. That means a lot coming from him, so if you can handle the heat, order the green curry.
BYOB so bring your fav drink. They do have great teas, and of course thai iced tea and thai iced coffee, delicious.

I came here after randomly remembering the suggestion of a friend a couple years back..

The exterior is very unassuming and it almost looks closed, but the interior is very classy and modern, and larger than I expected! 

We tried the pad thai and green curry. It was weird because the pad thai was obviously very well made but had almost no sweetness/tamarind taste which I was disappointed by. The green curry was only slightly spicy but still delicious! 

Took a star off because it was a little more pricey than Thai food tends to be for not a huge difference in quality... Maybe I should have tried the Laotian food instead - would definitely return for that!

I ate here once a long time ago (2009) and I thought the food here was good, but not outstanding.  The curry was barely spicy--perhaps we should have explicitly spelled it out.  But beyond this, it was flavorful but not really amazing or anything.  It also wasn't very filling.

I came back here in 2013 and...wow.  Just wow.  It was like a completely different restaurant...the food was really subtle and flavorful and completely unlike any Thai food I've had before.  I don't know if I hit it on an off day before, or if I ordered a dish better suited to my tastes the second time...but I've since come back, and tried quite a few different dishes here and it has been consistently top-notch.

This place is a little pricier than the average low-end restaurants that I like to eat at...it's hard to get out of here without spending $15 and it's easy to spend much more than that.  But I think the food is worth it.

Service was a little slow and inattentive the most recent time I came here.  I found that somewhat annoying.  But the food was so good that I'd totally keep coming back.  I've had lots of Thai food, and even some Lao food before, and I thought this was an unusually good restaurant of its type.
Love this vegetarian cafe. Great area with cool setting and clean fast service.Also great prices.

Living around the corner from Vientiane was the greatest thing I ever did in West Philly.  Now that I'm out in the mountains, I regret not taking advantage of it more than I did.

Let's look at the cons, first:
They're small.  Kinda stuffy in the summer.  Fills up quick.  Waiting for a table outside during the winter sucks.  Inconsistent interpretations of their heat scale (I've had mild-medium that was a 5 alarm fire in my mouth, i've had medium that was just right.  I dunno, just guess.) 

But the pros, oh, the pros.
Their fresh spring rolls. Squishy and chewy and full of mint and unicorns.  Maybe not really unicorns, but probably.  Actually better vegetarian than they are with meat.  Shrimp?  Whatever.  Get the tofu.

The soups.  Huge, unfinishable, delicious.  Just enough kick to warrant ordering 9 billion thai iced teas.  (did you know that you can get thai iced take as takeout?  I totally learned that here.)

My main course, every. Single. Time: Chicken Laarb.  I have never, in years of thai food, found another place that does laarb the way Vientiane does laarb.  Everywhere else, it's a weird vinegar-y appetizer salad thing, too sweet, kinda gross.  Here?  God, I don't know what they do here.  It's full of fish sauce and cilantro and lemongrass and scallions and magic fairy dust or something.  I would eat this for my last meal on earth.  Actually, I would eat the leftovers for my last night on earth.  (It's 100x better after it's been marinating in itself in the fridge overnight, and it's pretty damn perfect when it comes out of the kitchen.)

Dessert: does it even matter? Mango sticky rice, deep fried bananas, ice cream, who cares, it's gonna be delicious.

I fly 2000 miles for this meal every 6 months.  Not even kidding.

I came here to meet up with a group of friends and thought it was OK. It was quiet enough for talking and we were not rushed. 

 I wanted to try the Laotian food since I have had plenty of Thai.  I had the "Laah" with chicken which I could describe as chopped chicken mixed with scallions, herbs and it was a little tart with lemon or lime juice. I would say it was interesting but I did not love it and would not order that again.  The laah came served with "sticky rice" which is just as it sounds. The rice came in a little bamboo container which was cute except that they lined the container with plastic to keep the bamboo clean.  I don't really like eating food in plastic.  

The rest of the group seemed to enjoy their food. The things that looked interesting to me were the King Soup (came in a giant bowl!) the Triple Flavored, and the papaya salad.

They offer an early bird special Mon-Thurs which comes with a small cup of soup, a few small satay skewers and a main dish for $15, a good deal, especially as it is BYOB.

Overall I would say this is a decent place and probably one of the best options in a neighborhood not known for its cuisine. I would recommend it if you happen to be in the neighborhood but not if you have to make a special trip.

I am still craving these dishes weeks after trying them! I went with about 10 friends to celebrate a birthday last week. Because there were so many of us in our party, we were able to try so many items on the menu and ALL of them were outstanding! The dish I cannot stop thinking about: vegetarian naam salad. It will blow your mind. Tangy and sweet and crunchy and unbelievable. Another standout: King's Soup. Believe me when I tell you that it's the creamy coconut spicy soup you crave. The pad Thai is also not to be missed. 

The only reason I can't give this place five stars is because of how slow the service was. Granted, we were a large party...but the wait staff would sometimes disappear for 20-30 minutes at a time and it was over an hour and a half from the time I got there to the time I received my entree. 

BUT do not let the slow service stop you. Take advantage of its BYOB status and settle in with some nice wine and be patient for some very worth-the-wait dishes. 

We will absolutely be back!

I ate here summer of 2008. An adorable neighborhood restaurant gem that I will visit again next time I am in Philly. Delicious spring rolls, Pad Thai and Yum Salad and the best part to me was that you can bring your own bottle of wine! I believe they charged us a small corking fee, but it was very reasonable and really helped keep our bill down significantly. Quaint and lovely on both food and atmosphere...

a great authentic thai/lao place nestled in west philly! Highly recommend the Pad Kee Mao (w/ chicken)- strong flavors of thai basil and super fragrant noodle dish. Also got the Banh Xeo (Vietnamese pancake) that was super crispy and flavorful! Cash only, but also BYOB. Such a little gem in West Philly!

Hands down the best Thai food in Philly (and I'm hella picky) but yeah service is great and fast. Appetizers come really quickly and they don't shove food in your face while your appetizer is still on the table. But Tom yum here is fantasbulastic and the curry is yummm

This would be my first and last time here, I ordered papaya salad(that's what good) , larb with beef and beef jerky( both of them are super super super salty Iike they put a full of table spoon in there. That's so disappointed ( - -).

Hands down my favorite place to eat!

Pros: spicy, authentic, tasty, vegan-friendly

Cons: service can be a little spotty. If it had been better, I'd eat there a few times a week. It's that good.

Very good BUT ********CASH ONLY******** -- see second paragraph.
I took my daughter there for lunch. The place was nearly empty at the time, maybe 25% full?? The food was very good, the waiter friendly, and the service decent. I can't tolerate much spice, so I asked for low spice level and was satisified: good spicy taste, but not overwhelming for me. I'd have given it four stars or maybe even five except for the booby-trap:

I only had a little cash and was planning to pay with a card, till I opened  the bill folder and saw "CASH ONLY". I complained to the waiter, "There was no warning of this!" He pointed to the phrase on the regular and lunch menus-- very small print, lost amid other text unless you look closely. I had to walk with my cane 15 minutes to the nearest ATM and back; good thing it wasn't raining or I'd've just left. No sign outside, no indication on their website, and the ONLY warning of it on this Yelp review page is buried in Yelp's standard list:

I left frustrated and hungry...it took an hour to get our meals and they only seemed to finally bring out our food after we threatened to leave.  I was starving by that time and the meal barely satiated my hunger. I order the laab which was tasty but there was just not much too it. Just ground pork in a tangy sauce and some bean sprouts.  The sticky rice was interesting but not very tasty.  Was not worth the price. It was also crammed packed and so noisy you had to shout to be heard. I wouldn't go there hungry.  I won't be back.   I recommend their neighboring restaurant Dahlak, I've been going there for years and have never been disappointed

My wife and I ventured to this spot the other day for lunch. The funny thing is, we thought it was Vietnamese food because of the name. Ironically, there is a spot just around the corner called Vietnamese Cafe. Anyway, this is a Thai place.

The had a great lunch deal. For $9.99 you get a soup, appetizer and an entree. My wife and decided to share the appetizers. We got the Spring rolls and dumplings. Both were fantastic. 

I had the Spinach Soup with chicken and it was great. My wife got the Coconut Soup. She said it was okay, but not her thing. She did say it probably tasted the way it should, but realized afterwards she's not a huge coconut fan.

For the entree, I got the Pad Thai with chicken. I was perfect. I really enjoyed it. My wife got the Sweet Basil with chicken. She really liked it too.

All in all, it was a great experience, and the price was also great.
Amazing food (I love the tofu Lad Na), loads of vegetarian options, BYO, friendly staff, outdoor seating. Small, clean, comfortable. Only negative is that it's cash only.

This one here is definitely a hole in the wall kind of place. The place is simple and clean looking however the designs are kind of bland. The food is definitely the star here. When you see here, you have to order the Laos sausage. It comes with three sausages, sticky rice and two dipping sauce. One sauce is tomato based, think of a cross between spaghetti and tangy pizza sauce. The other is purée pepper sauce, terrific flavor but extra spicy! They also offer a lunch menu for 11 to 13 dollars which consists of soup, appetizer and entree. So far everything I had here is great, the Thai tea is especially amazing. Word of advice though, the food does take a bit to come out so make sure you have time, especially on a lunch break.

Vientiane is one of my top five favorites in West Philly, and one of my top ten favorites in the city. It's always a lovely dining BYO experience. The decor is elegant yet comfortable. It's a lovely place to have a special but cozy dinner although it's is equally suited to working into your rotation of takeout places. The staff is knowledgeable and everything runs smoothly even on busy nights. 

The food is terrific!!! Way better (more adventurous, more flavorful, less formulaic) than the other South East Asian option around the corner (cough cough, Vietnam Cafe). If you live in the area and are looking for something along the lines of Vietnamese or Laotian food, the only argument for going to Vietnam Cafe instead of Vientiane is the liquor license. Anyways...

I frequently order a duck dish of some kind. It's clearly cooked by an experienced chef and is always super tasty. I love the way they cook their rice-- it's magically chewy without being too sticky. My husband loves their house-made beef jerky and their yum salads. We also LOVE their coconut puddings. Honestly, sometimes we do take out just for the coconut pudding; it's that good. 

In sum; Vientiane is awesome. You should go.

The best part about this place besides the pho (I got tofu but my boyfriend got beef), and the crispy spring rolls was the service! The friendliness and smiles made us want to come back again. If In university city definitely should try this restaurant! It was my first Time eating pho and i truly enjoyed it! Definitely a 10/10! The only thing is they are cash only so come prepared
Amazing place for W. Philly!!! Everything I ever had was delicious. They are really nice and kind as well

So obsessed with this place now thanks to my friend! But seriously, best Penang curry ever and I love their vegetarian naam salad and Thai tea!! Service is also great and they're very friendly. I highly recommend this place if you guys are craving for some delicious Thai food! Mmm!

One of my favorite restaurants because they don't hold back on the flavor.  It's authentic laos food, not watered down dishes.  I love love love the papaya salad and order it with the crab sauce.  There are pieces of crab shell in the dish; that's the real deal.  My second favorite is the rice salad, perfect blend of sour and sweetness.  The laab is better when it's spicy.  You must order sticky rice to compliment these dishes and eat it with your hands. 

I noticed the restaurant expanded and the decor has been updated.  I was happy they didn't change the menu.  Keep it tasty.  Keep it real.
Some of the best food I've ever had. Quite surprising since Laotian has never been on my radar, but it is now!
They have a really nice selected of vegan options.  The Penang Curry is my new favorite food. I LOVE that it is byob. The service is hit or miss but the food is consistently good.
Love this place!!!! Food is awesome. Waiters and waitresses are very nice and attentive :) go eat here! You will not be let down.

Very much a neighborhood and college town kind of place. I went with relatives here last week, and I was expecting a very good experience, food wise (I don't think anywhere in Philly is outstanding for Thai, but this had good reviews). Others in my party had the King Soup, which is like a coconut soup. It was pretty good, but not amazing.

I ordered a chicken tom yum and chicken pad thai. The tom yum was solid, but a bit lacking on spice. My main gripe is with the chicken pad thai. I asked for it at a spice level of "medium." What I received was a mound of gummy-textured noodles, a few pieces of chicken, and some veggies, with no spice whatsoever.

Would order other items from the menu next time, but in no rush to return, even with the handicap that I give to Philly Thai restaurants (none are all that good, with Chabaa in Manayunk, or Ratchada, being the best of a meh bunch)

What a great place. Very unassuming but absolutely delicious!

Went around 615 on a weekday and had their daily dinner special, which included Tom Yum Soup, A noodle Dish, and Pork dumplings. 

Everything was absolutely delicious! The soup had great flavor and was a perfect portion size. The dumplings were well made and very tasty as well. Noodles were excellent and very flavorful. And it wasn't overly peanutty (That's a word right?). And the whole thing cost 18$! 

Got packed as we were leaving. Finally I have found a go to Thai place!

I would never notice this place if my friend didn't recommend it to me and 8'm glad i tried it out! Their sausages are the best! Tastes like home made and not too salty. The eggplant sweet sauce with half duck was my second fav. I don't think you will go wrong with any dishes. The only reason I don't give 5 stars is the long wait. We didn't order appetizers, and waited for 50min to get the first entree...

I've only been once, and it was fine but not enough to bring me back.  It was recommended by several people.  I've heard it described as Laotian-Thai.  I haven't eaten Laotian food anywhere else, but I've eaten a LOT of Thai food.  This place wasn't very exciting.  Maybe because I don't know from Laotian cuisine and didn't know what to order.  I LOVE green papaya salad, but theirs was just meh.  The other entrees were adequate--not bad at all.  You could do worse.

Best Thai in West Philly. I honestly don't know how this place isn't busy all the time. Flavorful dishes, fresh ingredients, good portions, and friendly staff. Lots of vegetarian options and their spice levels are no joke. Cash only is a little annoying, but the food makes up for it.
One of my favorite restaurants.  This is the real deal, if you like authentic Laos food.  Very happy with their papaya salad.

I've been here 3 times before and always loved it, especially the coconut soup  and mango sticky rice, but this time I'm pretty sure my boyfriend and I got food poisoning, either from the pad thai or pork dumplings.

This place is great! We have ordered catering from here twice, and they haven't disappointed yet; they arrive on time with lots of trays of food. We have a lot of vegetarians, and their tofu and noodle dishes are very popular. Their ingredients are very fresh, and they always give us lots of limes to go with our catering. You should definitely consider thinking outside of the box and get your next event catered by them.

No need to fly to Asia to get amazing Laotian/Thai food. Vientiane Café will satisfy your Asian cravings without breaking the bank. 

For starters we had the delicately sweet beef jerky and level 1  and level 3 papaya salad (note: level 1 was just the perfect spice level for me, level 3 was like throwing a fireball in my mouth) along with the grilled mixed vegetables and spring rolls. Everything was made to perfection. Although I wished they served sticky rice with the beef jerky, that can be remedied by ordering a side of sticky rice. 

We continued to gorge on naam (crispy rice with lime and peanuts), vegetable fried rice, crispy duck, shrimp red curry, and drunken noodles with chicken. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. As you can see we ordered a wide variety and we all left feeling like stuffed turkeys.

I live pretty close to Vientiane, but don't get to eat here much. The last time I went must have been 5-6 years ago, because when I went here recently they have expanded! They said they expanded 5 years ago. It's a bit dark inside, but the ambience is nice; minimally decorated with Laotian (at least that's what I think came from since it is Laotian restaurant) arts, comfortable environment, friendly service, and did not feel rushed out. The server answered our various questions, recommended few things, and the service was prompt. 
My friend ordered Aw Lao with beef. I got a taste of the broth and it was so nice! I don't know how to describe, but it was definitely a comfort food. Steamed sticky rice came in a straw container. I ordered Papaya salad Lao style with fermented crab, and spice level 3. At first I was taken back by the fishiness, but it kind of got addictive. I am Korean so I am used to spicy food, I think spice level 3 was a bit more spicy than I am used to. I have had spicier food, but I had rice to accompany the spicy food. Maybe next time I will adjust the spice level to 2 so I can enjoy some spice, but not have to blow my nose. Overall, the fishiness and spice added to the addictive quality of the salad! 
We also ordered chicken satay, I thought maybe it was a bit bland, but I also ate it without dipping into sauces. We did not take advantage of their lunch specials, but I would like to go back again to try their lunch specials.
Great cozy atmosphere. Food is very good. Service is fast. Overall it is one of the better places Baltimore ave. will definitely come back.

worst of the worst! 
Food is totally fake, tastes bad, but the service said that is how they cook here. Sucks

It's a significant trek out to Vientiane from Penn's campus but it's worth the trip. I think they're better than the general Thai/Malaysian/Laotian food near campus, and they have good lunch specials too.

We ordered the Pineapple Fried Rice.  It was delish! A decent serving of food .  We also had ginger tea.  I pretty much drank The Whole pot by myself.  The prices were also very reasonable. It's nice little restaurant

Really good authentic food. Baltimore avenue is looking beautiful! So many awesome places including this one. I only wish you took credit card too. I would come more often. I don't like paying in cash. Please respond to this when you take credit cards and we will frequent you place a lot more.

thai/laotian food. i don't really know what laotian food consists of, but my thai dish was pretty good. i got the red curry and although it wasn't spicy enough to my liking (it rarely is at thai restaurants), i still enjoyed it. the curry came in a bowl that was uniquely decorated, kinda cool in and of itself. the outside of the restaurant is decorated with all these loud colors, but inside, the place is dimly lit and has a kind of cozy feeling to it. definitely makes a good date location.

Disappointing. Everything is watered down and flavorless. The coconut soup is a far cry from authentic Tom Kha soup, and even the mango sticky rice, which is typically hard to screw up, was disappointing and served with a sauce so watered down it actually had the same consistency as water and ran off the rice & mangoes. 

Perhaps if you've never had authentic Thai or curry you'd be impressed; otherwise, this place is a huge miss. Don't waste your time or money.

My sister declared this her favorite restaurant in Phila, so I offered to take her here for dinner last night.  However, it should be noted that they dp not take credit cards (that was all I had on me) and so my sister took me out do dinner instead.  (A wonderful trick to pull if you are going with someone who is obligated to love you no matter what.)  But even though she had to pay, our dinner (apps to entrees to dessert to yum iced tea) was under 40 bucks.  Pretty awesome.

I'm a relative noob when it comes to Thai food and have never had Laotian, so I usually stick with shrimp pad thai.  So I've had my share of shrimp pad thai.  And this ranks up there with the best I've ever had.  Yum yum yum.  Sis got the red curry and it was like a sweet, spicy soup with lots of veg and chicken in it.  The spring rolls we split for an app were so tasty, light and fresh.  I tried the thai iced tea and I was scared it would be too sweet, but it was pretty close to a perfect compliment to my meal.  I ordered the rice pudding for dessert, expecting normal rice pudding, but it came in 4 little warm cups and was anything but normal, but decidedly delicious.  We were stuffed to the brim with delicious dinner.  (No sense in leaving too little to take home on your plate, of course.)

As for the service, it was above average.  Our waters were refilled, the food came out quickly, but it did take a while to flag down the waitress for the check.  Not a big deal at all, just us being in a hurry to get out the door to answer the call of nature ;)  

So go here.  It's a cheap, delicious, cozy restaurant.

I love this place!!! I've been twice so far, and the food is heaven. So far I've tried the naam salad (a perfect mix of sweet and spicy with a nice coconut flavor), the duck spring rolls (perfectly cooked and not greasy), the Cornish hen (flavorful but I wish they hadn't cut it into pieces), and my all time favorite THE KING'S SOUP!! I cannot even describe the deliciousness of this soup. I ordered mine with shrimp and tofu. The broth is a flavorful red curry with lots of veggies, and a mint garnish that is really good. I plan on going back and trying the fried fish, and the papaya salad.

I've eaten here 4 or 5 times over the past few years. It's a decent place, but I really don't think it's anything special. I've ordered vegetarian red curry, yellow curry, and eggplant sweet basil. I found the curries more flavorful and interesting than the eggplant. The eggplant was pretty nicely cooked (and eggplant is easy to over or undercook, so that's nice), but the flavor didn't seem that interesting -- lots of basil and not many other flavors supporting it. The curries are nice, very rich, flavorful, and spicy, but I didn't think they were a great value ($11). I do really like the sticky rice. My usual dining companion likes the beef and seafood red curries, but once ordered the Thai catfish and said that it was *horrible*, weirdly deep fried to death. He ate only 3 or 4 bites and couldn't stomach any more.

 I've never had lunch here, but dinner prices are not super cheap -- entrees are in the $11-$15 range. Tables are very close together, which occasionally leads to awkward moments because it is almost impossible to avoid overhearing other peoples' conversations and to avoid being similarly overheard by those at neighboring tables. Wait times can be a little long, but are generally bearable -- I've never had to stand around for more than 20 minutes.

 As busy as this place is, it's ridiculous that they don't accept cards...at the very least, they should post a prominent sign to warn people about their cash only policy.

I've always had good experiences here until tonight...

My boyfriend ordered the Mussels on their appetizer menu which he was really enjoying until he opened one and found it was entirely black (and rotten?  I don't eat Mussels but I'm sure they're not supposed to be black).  I don't think it would stop us going back because every other time we've been the food has been excellent - we just wouldn't order mussels!

The hostess allowed him to order something else on the menu with no problems but... He ordered Pad Thai which was ok but not the best in the city.

I ordered Aw Lao * soup (with sauteed lemongrass, shallots, chili, asian eggplant, dill: served with sticky rice, which was excellent.

Need to remember they only accept cash.

Lunch specials are also a great deal - soup, appetizer and main meal for less than $10.

Great vibe tonight though - the place was really busy and full of chatter.

after watching the "black metal vegan chef: pad thai" youtube video, i implanted into my friend's head the idea that pad thai must be consumed in the near future.  since she scoffed at the idea of actually MAKING the pad thai per the vid, she suggested this place near her abode.  my friend, her ladyfriend, and i sojurned to this previously unnoticed hole in the wall.  we beat the rush and got a table immediately.  the environment was quaint and warm.  i sensed that they didn't take credit cards and the host directed me toward an ATM down the street.  the wait staff was friendly and happy to serve us.  we brought a bottle of wine. my friends ordered their desired pad thai but i can never say no to red curry.  the waitress convinced me that salmon would go best with the curry and i asked her to kick up the heat on it.  she was right, the salmon worked great, though i could tell the filet was previously frozen. it was a bit tough and grilled without any seasonings.  the curry was spiced perfectly and the helping of food was enough to leave me full, but not overstuffed. i tasted my friend's pad thai, which also didn't have the heaviness that you'd expect from the dish.  it was light, airy, and full of flavor.  for desert i ordered the banana and chocolate spring rolls with sweet peach dipping sauce and they got the sweet coconut sticky rice.  i'm not a fan of coconut so i stuck to my sweet and melty spring rolls.. omg... so good.  get. them.  i WILL be back.

Came for a lunch special which is soup, app, and entree for 13-17 which is a decent deal. It was definitely a lot of food. The coconut soup was p good, although nothing really stood out- it was just a coconutty broth with veggies. The chicken satay were a bit dry, but still very flavorful- the sauce was perfect and really went well with the satay. 

I got the Panang curry medium spicy for my entree. All I can say is that it was alright. Spice level is as expected. My biggest complaint is that when it arrived, it looked like it was starting to separate into a layer of oil and a layer of lumpy inside. Still tasted pretty good, and they were generous with the beef so extra points for meat lovers. We got there at 1:30ish and there was no line, service was pretty fast also. Just watch out it is cash only. 

Still probably the best Thai place in west philly, although there really isn't much competition.

I decided to come here for University City Dining Days with two friends and it was well worth the $15.  We went on a Tuesday night, and the place was packed.  There are a few tiny tables on the sidewalk which could seat only 2 people each, so we had to sit inside.  The restaurant is very small, but it did not feel cramped to me.  Great ambience and great for a date or just a place to go with friends...my friends love that it's a byo, which one of the other good Thai places in University City, Thai Singa, is not.  Warnings: there is no AC and you must pay with cash.

So moving onto the food itself, I ordered the crispy pork spring roll, the chicken pad thai, and the mango sticky rice.  One friend ordered the chicken satay, the Paenang curry, and also the mango sticky rice.  My other friend ordered the green papaya salad, the stir-fried eggplant with chicken, and the banana chocolate spring roll.  The appetizers were all tiny: my spring roll was basically the size of a taquito, the chicken satay was only a few pieces of chicken on a skewer, and my friend's papaya salad had no papaya in it.  The entrees, however, were rather large and compensated for the bite-size appetizers.  By default, I always have to try the pad thai before making any judgment on a Thai restaurant.  I really enjoyed my pad thai here; it was flavorful and the chicken was very tender and moist.  My friends' entrees were not as good--both were so-so.  As for dessert, my friend's banana chocolate spring roll was delicious--perfectly pairing of crispy and mushy textures, and nice and warm.  My mango sticky rice was deconstructed, which was not how I have usually seen it, but it was pretty good (almost as good as the mango sticky rice from my favorite Thai restaurant at home!).  It was a little too flimsy though.  The Thai iced tea was also delicious, and I got it for free because I had to ask for it twice.

I would definitely recommend checking this place out!  And be sure to have the guava candy they give you with the check. :)

King soup the curry the grilled veggie and the papaya salad are my favorites !!! I only eat here when my friend works here or the manager because the new waiters usuallly mess up my order!!! But over all love the ambience and the authentic food!!!

Decent Thai food, sweet setting. We had great service though, & that's what the 4 stars are for. They have an ample amount of seating now that they have taken over the storefront next door. Cash only.
Love this place ! Byob ...and you have to try the naam salad ...to dye for, I go there sometimes just to eat that !

I very much enjoy coming for the affordable and deceptively filling 3-course lunch.  For your $10 you get a soup, a small appetizer, and a main entree from a limited menu.  I always get the Tom Yum soup which is delightfully spicy, but also very light.  You can't go wrong with any of the appetizer choices. 
The main courses include Thai curries, Pad Thai, sweet ginger, and one or two other things that I can't remember.  I really like the green curry and the sweet ginger with any choice of protein.
The staff is very friendly, the clientele is all over the spectrum, and it looks like they are planning to expand their space to include the place next door so there will be even more room.
I have yet to be there for dinner, but lunch is solid.

To call this "Thai Food" is an insult to the people of Thailand. We ordered the Chicken Satay and Chicken Pad Thai. Two staples of Thai food. Both dishes that Every thai place should have mastered. 
My first issue came when I found not one, but TWO pieces of hair in my Pad Thai. Two different pieces of hair. Different lengths, and different colors. Unacceptable, but I was hungry, so I pulled them out and let it slide. 
My main issue was that this food was just disgusting. I have never tasted food so absolutely bland and flavorless before. The chicken was dry, the noodles were one large clump, and the vegetables were soggy. Everything, both the satay and the pad thai, was just gross. There was very little flavor in anything. 
I will be the first to admit that Philadelphia is not the place to go for good Thai food, but this was just so unbelievably gross that we ate a few bites each and threw the rest in the trash.
I can absolutely assure you I will never be back.

I was very excited to eat at this place which has 4 star rating. Also I looooove Asian food! To my disappointment the food was very blend, meat was tough and service very friendly but slow.  I take it that we might be spoiled by North Jersey restsurants, where we have a big Asian population. I do not think they would survive in our area!
It's a big place, and it's BYOB so that's cool. But I just didn't think the flavors were anything close to what I get in Queens. I'm forgiving, but I wouldn't go back.

After an initial bad experience and then giving them a second chance, I was still disappointed. The size of their entrees are smaller than my doggie bag I take home after eating at other similar restaurants. 

Skimpy amount of vegetables in the curry dishes. Pad Thai would be good if it was spiced. Fried tofu appetizer was amazingly bland, not even salt added. The banana and chocolate dessert was tasty but hardly worth the visit. 

There are too many tables in too small a space with too few servers. You can do better.

Talk about an under the radar gem. After living in Philly for over 6 years and loving Asian food, we finally made it over to West Philly and tried this BYOB, and all I will say is that we have gone back every week for 5 straight weeks. It's that good. And cheap. And did I mention, BYOB.

First, my girlfriend is a vegetarian and this place is absolutely wonderful for her. If you know of the "Best Thing I Ever Ate" on Cooking Channel, her choice for the Asian category is the Vegetarian Naam Salad. And let me tell you, as a meat eater, it is just so damn satisfying. They puff and crisp rice, and then serve it with lime, cilantro, peanuts, chili, and give you lettuce cups to use as a vessel to transport it from the plate to your mouth. The perfect blend of crunchy, salty, acidic, and spicy, we could eat it every day. And, it's healthy! 

For the entrees, my girlfriend loves the King Soup with tofu. It's a red curry Thai-style broth, filled with rice noodles, tofu, bean sprouts, and some veggies. Perfect for a winter day. I would recommend the Laotian Sausages with sticky rice. They are homemade with lemongrass, chili, and other spices, and serviced with this amazing spicy acidic dipping sauce. Little rice, little sausage, and some dip, perfect bite. I look forward to continuing to try their Lao speciality dishes. 

Finally, they have all the "normal" Thai style noodles, curries, and rice dishes, and they truly are awesome, way better than the normal take out stuff you can get at all the "normal" Thai restaurants in the city.

Overall, everything is delicious, the service is great, and it's BYOB. What else can you want? Do yourself a favor, make the drive from anywhere in the city to this West Philly gem. And enjoy!

Thanks to Vientiane Cafe, my eternal craving for mango sticky rice is finally satisfied! I had been looking for sweet sticky rice with mango at quite a few Thai restaurants, but the closest one I could find before I found Vientiane Cafe was Erawan, which is quite a distance away. The mango sticky rice was perfect; the coconut milk sweetened the sticky rice just enough and complemented the slightly tart mango slices perfectly. The sticky rice was warm and cooked perfectly--not too hard or too mushy.

I also have tried Vientiane Cafe's papaya salad with anchovy sauce, as well as its sweet basil tofu dish. I liked them both equally. The papaya salad tasted different from papaya salads I've tried at other restaurants, but it was a good kind of different. The sweet basil tofu dish was flavorful. I expected there to be a ton of basil in the dish, but there actually were not very many basil leaves on my plate. I wouldn't mind more basil to be honest since I love basil, but I can see how having too many basil leaves could overpower the dish. Overall, I enjoyed my lunch here, although I probably would not come back when I'm pressed on time since the service is on the slower side.

Look no further, Vientiane is here! Every time I'm craving thai food, Vientiane is the first thing that comes to my mind. I've been here about numerous times over the last few years and it always hit the right spot. Love everything I've tried here and can't wait to go back to this West Philly gem.

Pros:
- BYOB!!! Need I say more? 
- Great service! The wait staff gives great recommendations and is always accommodating 
- Almost every dish has a Vegetarian/gluten-free options 
- Good ratio of protein to vegetables to grains for each dish
- Tofu here out of this world! I actually prefer it over meat options 
- Great place for lunch, dinner dates or small group gatherings  

Must eats - 
King soup - enough for two! but you might not want to share, I didn't haha
Tamarind wings 
Chicken Satay 
Anything Curry! 
Aw Lao 
Papaya salad 

Tips: 
- cash only :( 
- Fall/early winter 3 course special $20 only on Weekdays 5-6:30pm
- Call-ahead on weekend

I think i just need a tad more bit authenticity to bump this up to a 4.

Pad see ew- 3 stars. This was extremely Americanized in my opinion. It tasted fine, but it definitely wasn't Thai. The noodles were cooked well, and so was the beef. but the sauce -- it honestly tasted like the whole thing was sauteed in a bunch of soy sauce. That was highly disappointing. 

Tom yum: I'll give this a 4 star. A little bit of sour, a little bit of heat and the shrimp was nicely cooked. I enjoyed this.

Chicken in Yellow Curry: 3.5 stars. I thought this dish was executed nicely. It tasted much more authentic than the pad-see-ew.

I may return for the lunch special the server spoke of. She said it's something like $10.95 for 3 courses for lunch? TELL ME MORE :) If I go, I shall update :)

Dinner at this popular local restaurant was preceded by a brief wait until a table was open but was worth the wait.

The restaurant is a lot bigger than what appears to be from the front entrance with a long room on the other side of the double store width.
As a starter, the chicken satay was more than satifying with a delicious flavorful sauce accompanying the chicken. The spring rolls were equally as tasty.

The entrees, one of which was Eggplant Sweet Basil had
bell peppers, onions, and carrots in a sweet chili sauce in the dish and was delectable. My Green Curry entree with onions, basil, green beans, broccoli, carrots and green chilis in a coconut broth had just the right heat for my taste and was very good.

Another entree of Pad Kee Mao - tofu flat noodles that is pan-fried with bean sprouts, Thai basil, vegetables in a spicy garlic sauce was ordered my one of our dining companions on a previous visit and did not disappoint.

We diffinitely plan another visit to the Vientiane Cafe when visit this area in the near future.

I can't say enough about this place. Everything I have ever had was delicious - panang curry, egglplant/dill/sticky rice, Pad Kee Mow (so tasty that it took me a year to stop ordering it), red curry, yelloy curry, green curry- try it all, rice noodles, curries.  It's not Thai, as some people claim, but Laotian, which is why many people don't recognize dishes on the menu, or certain flavor combination. 

I don't give 5 stars based on food, though. I love this place because it is a neighborhood joint, because you can eat outside in the summer, because it is a BYOB, because it is CHEAP for the amount of food you get, because when you're there you feel happy just knowing that everyone else is having as good a time as you are. It's not fancy, it's just fantastic. 

Also, there are so many vegetarian options, it's always a hard choice to decide between something new and something that I've had beofre and loved. Really, I could go here every day.

I had the Chicken Pad Thai. It was phenomenal. I love that they can make your dish as spicy or as mild as you want it. I recommend a heat level of two to start off with. I felt like I got a plentiful portion for how much I paid and I left extremely full! I will definitely be going back and bringing friends. Everything on their menu looks amazing.

My first introduction to Thai was 12 years ago at Lemon Grass...that became the barometer by which I judged all other Thai...until I ate there in July 2012 and it was terrible...I've never looked back.  I have however continued on my quest for the new gold standard...on my first visit I always order the same thing - Tom Kha Gai and Pad Kee Mao...if they're able to handle the basics then I'll put them on my rotation, which lately has been Thai Singha House, Thai Kuu (just for convenience to meet friends), and Pattaya Grill.  

I actually decided that I would just go back to making my own (especially since my friend showered me with spices from her trip to Thailand), that was until I finally stopped into Vientiane Cafe.  I've been driving by it for years, unsure of what was behind the shadowy threshold.  I was on Penn's campus and just didn't want to be disappointed at Pattaya so I went out on a limb with Vientiane.  

First, they have customer service...after eating at Lemon Grass for so many years, I was stunned by the attentiveness of the server...and when I said that the soup was a tad too sweet, he returned with a lime "to balance the flavor" and it did.  I attributed this ethic to the fact that they appeared to be second generation; hence, they understand the customer experience. 

Second, the food was very good...after I added the lime, the "coconut milk soup" was spot on, and the "drunken noodles" were just the right spiciness, achieved with chili oil and dried chilies, and for the first time ever, a nice balance between chicken, veggies, and noodles.  

I plan to return for another prix-fixe lunch and an early-bird dinner.  This was certainly a pleasant surprise that has been hiding in plain sight.

I love the food here! My favorite dishes are: 

1) Penang Curry (I highly recommend it!) 
2) Shrimp Dumplings
3) Pad See Ew
4) Drunken Noodles

I also love that it's a BYO. It can get pretty crowded, the service is sometimes a little too slow and it's CASH ONLY. It's a cute place nonetheless and there is rarely a wait for a table.

Easily one of my favorite restaurants in Philly. I've been here more times than I can count and every time is better than the last. Food is absolutely exceptional! Service is always perfect. Check it out :-) Thank me later!

My GF had been wanting to get me to try a bunch of her old restaurants spots from where she used to live (West Philly). We had gone to Vietnam Cafe a few weeks back and it was amazing so I was REALLY excited to go here after reading the menu. I love asian food and one of my favorite soups is Tom Yum soup so I was really excited to try the Yum Salad (which is odd because soup is better than salad).

Anyways they had a early bird dinner special where you could get a salad an app and an entree so I went with that.

The salad came out first and it speaks of a "spicy lemon dressing". Tom Yum soup is spicy so this was in line. The first bite I had tasted awful, I couldn't describe it but it brought back memories of something gross. All the other bites however didn't have that same taste (I was actually trying to figure out what the taste was with additional bites, but never got it again. Not a bad thing I guess). The dressing was in no way spicy, it was very sweet. Gave it a 2 out of 5.

The next thing was the chicken satay. Either they cooked it on top of fish or used tongs they used fish on, but it tasted like fish. I like chicken and I like fish, but I don't want my chicken tasting like fish. 1 out of 5

Next I got the Ginger Sauce with shrimp. They have a spicy level, and 5 options. I like things very spicy, but with Thai food I know it can get quite extreme. I went with Very Spicy, which is 1 notch down from their spiciest. When it came there wasn't even a hint of heat from the spices. Personally I think they used the sweet basil sauce instead as it almost tasted like a very sweet tomato sauce. 1 out of 5.

No interest in going back here again. Vietnam Cafe is a much better choice. Won't hold it against the GF, she's recommended some of my favorite places in the city to eat, she's due a dud.

This is probably the best Thai food I've had, ever. That might not be saying much, since I've only tried a handful of places, but from my two experiences dining here, there really isn't much I would've done differently. The first time, I got the Pad Kee Mao (due to a fellow Yelper's raving on how it took her a year to stop ordering it!) and I almost had to fight off my boyfriend's prying fork off my plate. The tofu was perfectly cooked, the noodles were fantastic in texture and taste, and the vegetables fresh and abundant. I had a few bites of the boyfriend's panaeng curry, which was also quite the delight-- perfectly creamy and peanut buttery, with an extra kick of something I've never been able to replicate in cooking at home since (and I've tried). The second time, I went with a friend at around 9:30, and for some strange reason the place was packed. Our 20-minute wait was worth it though, and my Eggplant sweet basil didn't disappoint. The rice was a little too greasy for my tastes, but the eggplant was delicious and satisfying. 

As for the appetizers, I've tried the fresh Spring rolls and the deep-fried tofu. The Spring rolls themselves were just okay-- the filling couldn't been better.  However, the 2 dipping sauces more than made up for the rolls' ho-humness with their very different, yet complimentary, flavors. The fried tofu was deeeeelicious, but probably not something to which I'd subject my heart every time.  I still really want to try the veggie dumplings (if anyone has, shoot me a message!)

The place is BYOB, but with all that food I found water was plenty. The service is fast and friendly, and the interior is cute (bonus: magazines by the window sills while you're waiting...I caught up on some interior decorating fluff via Domino).

Can't believe I've waited so long to go here. Lemon Grass is closer, but (no offense) only a tenth as good.  With the average dish under $10 and lots of vegetarian options, I'm sure this restaurant will be receiving more of my had-earned cash in the year to come!

PROS: Light, medium-portioned dishes that leave you satisfied (not bloated)
CONS: Stuffy & simple dining space, mediocre service

Vientiane Cafe is cheap for the quality of food you receive! The steamed dumplings were more like veggie raviolis and the sweet and sour tilapia was a bit too sweet (albeit the fish itself was moist and cooked to crispy perfection). Overall, the dishes are not mind-blowingly good, but they won't break the bank either! Worth a visit. BYOB!
There food  is everything taste as good as my mom's cookin and the stuff was very friendly. Everything I had was great. My new favorite place to eat . Just like home cookin

A solid, clean Lao-Thai BYOB just outside of University City on Baltimore Ave. Street parking was not a problem. 
Staff was friendly and service was good. 
I would've liked my Panang curry a bit spicier, but I think they would turn up the heat if I asked them on my next visit -- and I plan on returning.

This used to be my hood. I moved to center city, but when I am craving yummy fresh lao and vietnamese here is where I go.

The sticky rice is amazing. The service and wait can be mediocre, but its worth it. 

They do not accept cash, but there is an atm arround the corner in the corner store. There is a municpal lot right behind it too! BYOB as well!

I love the food here and I would love to give a five star review, but I'm taking 2 stars off for false advertising.  Their hours are listed as 4-9pm, but they close their kitchen at 8:30.  That should be noted on the website for folks who want to order.
Cute place. Great food. I've tried several dishes here (all vegetarian) and loved them. The eggplant sweet basil and green curry were great. I recommend trying fried tofu as an appetizer.

It's great to see an underrepresented country and its cuisine stand alone and shine proudly in a city highly saturated with Thai and Vietnamese restaurants. It was my first time trying Laotian food and it was an exquisite first impression that only makes me want to keep exploring more! 

The location is very accessible via car or public transit.  Just don't confuse it with "Vietnam Cafe" around the corner. 

The atmosphere was authentic and interesting with cultural artifacts like tapestry and musical instruments from Laos. The real plants and flowers were a nice touch. The servers were sincere and courteous, even when it got really busy. 

We started with nam nam vegan salad which tasted like very savory crispy fried rice, paired well with the freshness of iceberg lettuce.

For dinner, we got the King Soup and the pan seared fish (tilapia)wrap. The king soup was a coconut red curry with vermicelli noodles , mint, cabbage, bean sprouts and tofu. It was very nourishing to eat on a cold day but a bit on the salty side, so was my least favorite. It also resembled curries I've tried before at Thai restaurants so it was not as pleasantly surprising as compared to the other Laotian dishes we tried. Still, a pretty solid curry. 

The pan seared fish wrap was our favorite. The fish filet was flavored and cooked very well (albeit without skin)  and the there was an arrangement of finely cut fresh ginger and lemongrass, tomato, shiso herb, starfruit, cucumber, and vermicelli noodles, as options to wrap with the fish. The only challenge was the the iceberg lettuce was cut in triangular chunks,  so it wasn't big enough for wrapping all the other contents and things easily fell out or into the sauce. The highlight was definitely the spicy tamarind sauce, thick, sweet and tangy.

The mango sticky was somewhat disappointing to end our delicious meal because the mangoes were not in season,  so not very flavorful and the proportion of sticky rice to fruit was not enough. 

Overall, highly recommend trying the Laotian appetizers and entrees dishes on the menu.

Great BYOB serving up delicious food. The menu features a wealth of vegan & vegetarian options and their tofu is delicious (must be homemade cause it's nothing like what they sell in stores). Everything is very flavorful and fresh tasting. Just be warned that when they say a dish is spicy, they really mean it.

Came here for New Year's Eve with a party of 3. Called ahead to see about reservations but they said to just come in. They were right. Very kind people all around. The wait was 30 to 40 minutes and they let us run to the bar around the corner and called us when it was ready. They were a bit abrupt on the phone but hey it's new years eve and you have to expect a little frustration. The food was awesome! The beef jerkey was one of the best things I have ever eaten. You need to get it. I'm a Polish girl, we are meat conissuers and this was some of the best. The ambiance was pretty good. Cute, little place. The tables were kind of rickity but who really cares. This place really made our new years great and we will definetly be back soon.

Yes!!!! Finding a place in the city with great food and great costumer service is not the easiest, but I must say, I've found it. Byob, great food, LOTS of vegetarian options and pleasant servers make this place one of my favs!! 
We decided to come on Christmas Eve. This is actually my 2nd time here. I have no idea why I don't come more often. It's definitely a hidden gem.
Best Pad Thai this side of town. Must try the homemade beef jerky! Be aware it is cash only and they don't have an ATM available in the restaurant.

This restaurant is not a place I take dates. Why? I just shovel everything put in front of me into my mouth, as though I have five minutes to live. 

Alright. If you need seating for more than two, you may have to wait. The restaurant is small and you may be nearly sitting on top of the table next to you. 

I'm obsessed with their pad thai. Vegetables are always of perfect consistency. Their vegetable coconut soup is awesome. I've tried eating other things but really... no sense in toying with perfection. 

I've had the distinct pleasure of eating here with the below yelper Marissa B and she's not joking about the mango sticky rice OR this place haunting you from the other side of the country. Their thai ice tea is worth drowning in.

Too bad, because I love Thai food...

I just moved into the area and have been checking out the local businesses and restaurants.  I am excited to see all the Thai restaurants and this place was my first stop.  The restaurant is super cute and clean.  The service is excellent.  I'm disappointed to say the food is just not on-par with everything else.  It seems this place likes to cater to the white man...sorry...not sorry.  I like my ethnic foods to...well...taste ethnic and not watered down.  I ordered the Tom Yum Koong soup and the broth was just ok but what confused me was why there was broccoli, bell peppers and carrots in it.  I'm from southern CA and have been to plenty of Thai restaurants to know that this is just plain weird.  My spicy basil eggplant and tofu was also just ok...super oily.  My friend ordered the Papaya salad, which was the only thing we finished eating because it was SO delicious and the red curry with chicken.  Again, why there was broccoli, carrots, green beans and  bell peppers in here is beyond me.  The curry itself was just ok...a little bland imo but edible.  Just weird to have those ingredients in the curry.  I MIGHT give them another try again at a later time since they were so nice and the papaya salad was so good but I will be checking some other Thai spots first.

I love this place.
Its a cute place to go on a date - small and cozy with good mood lighting. However, it fills up quick - be warned! 
My partner and I are vegetarians, so we only ever get the curry and the pad thai...and its all we ever need in the world.
I wanted to update, since my last review I have been back more times than I can count and have only had good service.

We've been so many times because the food is great. There are a ton of gluten free and vegetarian options. The ban xeo is my personal favorite. It doesn't look like much from the outside but definitely worth checking out!!

We came here with friends in our hunt for a good Thai-Laos meal. We ordered the bahn-xeo, pad kee mao, spicy basil fried rice and green curry. The only dish that disappointed us was the green curry which was a little too sweet and watered down but the rest of the meal was pretty flavorful.
Wonderful local Thai food place... another lovely BYO in West Philly. Definitely check this place out :)
The food is fresh and delicious!  Some of the best of its kind in Philadelphia. Service is often slow, but the food is worth the wait. Highly recommend

Fantastic Thai/Lao food.  The best in the city, actually the most authentic Thai/Lao food I've had in America.  I spent a lot of time here, the cook was from Isaan and knew how to cook actual Thai/Lao food, so I'd highly recommend it to anyone that was looking for something a little more authentic that the standard Pad Thai.
